li.p: For each of our basic centrality measures (degree centrality, closeness centrality, betweenness centrality), prove that if you add the edge (u,v) to G then the centrality of vertex u does not decrease. (Mathematically, we say that the centrality of u is weakly increasing for edge additions at u.)

Which of these centrality measures are weakly increasing at every vertex w when you add a particular edge (u,v)? For those that are weakly increasing, give a proof. For those that are not weakly increasing, give an example where adding the edge (u,v) decreases the centrality at some other vertex w.

statement.p:
Let G be an undirected tree. Removing the edge (u,v) splits the graph into two disjoint trees G_1 and G_2 where u \in V(G_1) and v \in V(G_2). Suppose that G_1 has N_1 vertices and G_2 has N_2 vertices. Prove that the (un-normalized) closeness centralities of u and v satisfy
\frac{1}{c_u^C} + N_1 = \frac{1}{c_v^C} + N_2.

Let G be an undirected tree on N vertices. Let v be a vertex with degree k_v = k. Removing the vertex v splits the tree into k \geq 2 disjoint trees G_1,G_2, \ldots, G_k. Suppose that tree G_i contains N_i vertices for 1 \leq i \leq k. Show that the (un-normalized) betweenness centrality of v satisfies
c_v^B = (N-1)^2 - \sum_{i=1}^k N_i^2

In a lazy walk on a directed graph, at each step, we can either stay at the current vertex or move to an adjacent vertex. So a lazy walk of length k is a sequence of vertices v_0, v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_k where for 1 \leq i \leq k, we either have v_i = v_{i-1} or (v_{i-1}, v_i) is an arc of G.
Let A be the adjacency matrix of a directed graph G, so that a_{ij} is 1 if (i,j) is an arc and is 0 otherwise. Using induction on k \geq 0, prove that the ijth entry of (I+A)^k counts the number of lazy walks of length k from vertex i to vertex j.

In this problem, you will prove part of the Perron-Frobenius Theorem. Let \bx, \by \in \R^n. Recall that the dot product is defined as \bx \cdot \by = \bx^{\top} \by, and that \bx and \by are orthogonal when \bx \cdot \by = 0.
Let A be an n \times n matrix. Prove that (A\bx) \cdot \by = \bx \cdot A^{\top} \by.
Let A be a symmetric matrix, so that A = A^{\top}. Let \lambda and \mu be distinct nonzero eigenvalues with corresponding (right) eigenvectors \bu and \bv, so that A \bu = \lambda \bu and A \bv = \mu \bv. Prove that (A \bu) \cdot \bv =0.
Explain why part (b) ensures that the eigenvectors \bu and \bv are orthogonal.

Let A be the adjacency matrix for a connected, undirected and aperiodic graph. Recall that the Frobenius-Perron Theorem guarantees that the symmetric matrix A has real eigenvalues \kappa_1 \geq \kappa_2 \geq \cdots \geq \kappa_n with corresponding orthonormal eigenvectors \bu_1, \bu_2, \ldots , \bu_n. Furthermore
The eigenvalue \kappa_1 has multiplicity one, and \kappa_1 > | \kappa_i | for 2 \leq i \leq n.
The corresponding eigenvector \bu_1 has non-negative entries.
In this problem, you will show that when n \geq 3, we have \kappa_1 \geq 1.
Let \bx = A \bone. Explain explain why \bx \geq \bone, (meaning x_i \geq 1 for all i), and explain why there is at least one j such that x_j > 1.
The orthonormal eigenvectors \bu_1, \bu_2, \ldots , \bu_n form a basis for \R^n. So there exist c_1, c_2, \ldots, c_n such that
\bone = c_1 \bu_1 + c_2 \bu_2 + \cdots + c_n \bu_n.
Consider
A \bone = A(c_1 \bu_1 + c_2 \bu_2 + \cdots + c_n \bu_n).
Explain why \kappa_1 < 1 leads to a contradiction to your observations in part (a).

Let G be a simple undirected graph with n \times n adjacency matrix A. Since G is undirected, its adjacency matrix is symmetric: A = A^{\top}. Therefore, the Katz centrality \bx \in \R^n is limiting value of the Katz recursion

for some choice of \alpha. Let \kappa_1, \ldots \kappa_n be the eigenvalues of A with corresponding eigenvectors \bu_1, \bu_2, \ldots, \bu_n. By the Frobenius-Perron Theorem, \kappa_1 > | \kappa_i | for 2 \leq i \leq n, and the eigenvectors form a basis for \R^n. Note that \bu_1 is the eigenvector centrality of G.
You will show that as \alpha \rightarrow 1/\kappa_1, the Katz centrality becomes proportional to eigenvector centrality.
Pick any eigenvector \bu_i and consider the recursive process
\by_{i,1} &= \bu_i
\by_{i,t} &= \alpha A \by_{i,t-1} + \bu_i \mbox{ for } t \geq 2.
Use induction on t \geq 1 to prove that
\by_{i,t} = \left( 1 + \alpha \kappa_i + \alpha^2 {\kappa_i^2} + \cdots + \alpha^{t-1} {\kappa_i^{t-1}} \right) \bu_i = \sum_{k=0}^{t-1} (\alpha \kappa_i)^k \bu_i.
Pick our constant \alpha > 0 such that
\frac{1}{ \kappa_1} < \alpha < \frac{1}{|\kappa_i|}
for 2 \leq i \leq n. Show that
\lim_{t \rightarrow \infty} |\by_{1,t} | = \infty
while for 2 \leq i \leq n,
\lim_{t \rightarrow \infty} |\by_{i,t}| \mbox{ is finite}.
You will need to use one (or both) of the following facts about geometric sums and geometric series:
1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \cdots + r^t = \sum_{k=0}^{t} r^k = \frac{r^{t+1} -1}{r-1}
and
1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \cdots = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} r^k = \left\{ \begin{array}{cl} \frac{1}{1-r} & \mbox{if } |r| < 1, \\ \infty & \mbox{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.
We know that the eignvectors \bu_1, \ldots, \bu_n form a basis for \R^n (thanks, Frobenius-Perron!). In particular, we have
\bone = c_1 \bu_1 + c_2 \bu_2 + \cdots + c_n \bu_n
for some choice of c_1, \ldots, c_n \in \R. Let us assume that c_1 \neq 0. Use parts (a) and (b) to show that the limiting value
\bx_t = \alpha A \bx_{t-1} + \bone
of the Katz recursion is basically proportional to the eigenvector centrality \bu_1. In other words, show that
\lim_{t \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\bx_t}{| \bx_t |} = \frac{\bu_1}{| \bu_1|}.

Now let's talk about what happens to the Katz centrality as \alpha \rightarrow 0. You will show that for very small \alpha, the Katz centrality gives a vertex ranking that is equivalent to degree centrality, meaning that the order of the ranking is the same as the degree centrality ranking. This time, we will start with the following equation, which is satisfied by the limiting solution to the Katz recursion:
\bx = \alpha A \bx + \bone.
Explain why A \bone < n \bone.
If B is an n \times n matrix and suppose that (I-B) is invertible, then we know that
(I-B)^{-1} = \sum_{j=0}^{\infty} B^j = I + B + B^2 + \cdots + B^j + \cdots.
Use this fact to show that
\bx = \bone + \alpha A \bone + \alpha^2 A^2 \bone + \cdots + \alpha^s A^s \bone + \cdots
Next, let \alpha = 1/m where m > 0 is a very large number (to be determined later). Use parts (a) and (b) to show that
\bx = \bone + \frac{1}{m} A \bone + \bb
where \bb is a vector satisfying
| \bb | < \frac{n}{m (m-1)} \bone.
Finally, take m = n^2 and look at \bx - \bone. Explain why ordering of the vertices by the entries in \bx - \bone gives the same ranking as degree centrality (as long as n \geq 2). A similar argument holds for any m > n^2, so as \alpha \rightarrow 0, the ranking is the same as the degree centrality ranking.

exercise.title: Hubs and Authorities as an Eigenvector

idx.h: Hubs and Authorities as an Eigenvector

statement.p:
Let A be the adjacency matrix of network G. Define the 2n \times 2n matrix
B = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 0 & A \\ A^{\top} & 0 \end{array} \right].
Let \bv = (v_1, \ldots, v_{2n})^{\top} be the right eigenvector for the largest eigenvalue \lambda of B^2, that is B^2 \bv = \lambda \bv. Show that \bh = (v_1, \ldots, v_n)^{\top} and \ba = (v_{n+1}, \ldots, v_{2n})^{\top} where \bh is the vector of hub scores of G and \ba is the vector of authority scores of G.

The Theater and Dance Department is staging a production. This is a complex and time intensive process, requiring the coordination of many simultaneous creative efforts. The cast and crew were given an organizational workflow of who they should approach when they have questions, depending upon their role in the production.

The csv file TheaterProductionEdges.csv represents this structure as a weighted directed graph. The weight of arc (u,v) is the number of people in role u. Use Gephi to investigate this complex system. You must:
Create a graph layout using the features of Gephi to make an informative data visualization that helps you to communicate your insights. You can include multiple visualizations, if you like.
Use the centrality measures that we have discussed to determine the ways in which various roles are important. These are: degree centralities, betweenness centrality, eigenvector centrality, PageRank centrality.
Identify the first, second, and third most important roles in the network. Do some web searching so that you understand the responsibilities of those roles. With that background information, do your results make sense? Comment on the efficacy of the various centrality measures in understanding this network.
